Okay, so I'm trying to solve this genetics problem about guinea pigs. Let me read through it again carefully. The scenario is that a scientist crossed two guinea pigs, both with black coats. Black hair is dominant over white, so we know that the dominant trait (black) is expressed, and the recessive trait (white) isn't visible in the presence of the dominant version. The offspring's traits are ¾ black and ¼ white. The question is asking about the genotypes of the parents, specifically which combination would result in these offspring ratios. Let me break down what I remember from Mendelian genetics. Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. Given that all three-quarters of the offspring have black coats and one-quarter has white, that suggests a 3:1 ratio. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white). So, if we're looking at dihybrid crosses or other combinations, how do the parents' genotypes look? The options given are A to J, but let me list them: A. Bb × Bb  
B. BB × BB and Bb × bb  
C. bb × Bb  
D. bb × bb  
E. bb × BB  
F. Bb × bb  
G. Bb × BB  
H. BB × Bb  
I. BB × bb  
J. BB × BB Wait, actually, looking back, the user provided the possible answers as G, H, I, J, etc., but perhaps some of my notes might be off. Let me think more clearly. The key here is figuring out the genotype of the parents that would produce such a ratio when crossed. Since the ratio is ¾ black to ¼ white, this implies that in each offspring, there must be at least one dominant allele (B) present because the recessive condition (bb) leads to white. If a parent were homozygous recessive (bb), then every offspring would inherit a b from both parents, resulting in bb and hence white coats. So any parent who is bb would cause all their offspring to have white coats. However, since the parents aren't all producing white, they can't both be bb. Therefore, at least one parent must be heterozygous (Bb), giving some chance of passing on the dominant allele. But wait, let me consider the possible parent combinations: Option D is bb × bb. If both parents are bb, all their offspring would get bb from each, leading to all white coats. That doesn't match the given data, so D is out. Similarly, E is bb × BB. The bb parent will always give b, while the BB parent gives B. So all offspring would be Bb, resulting in black coats. Again, no white coats, so E is not correct. Now, F is Bb × bb. The bb parent always gives b, while Bb can give either B or b. So half the offspring will be Bb (black) and half bb (white). That matches the given ratio exactly. So F is a possibility. Looking further, let's check other options. Option A is Bb × Bb. Both parents are heterozygous. Using a Punnett square, the possible offspring would be BB (25%), Bb (50%), and bb (25%). But according to the problem, ¾ are black, which includes BB and Bb, and ¼ are white (only bb). That fits perfectly. So option A also works. Option C is bb × Bb. Similar to F, the bb parent gives b, and Bb can give B or b. So again, 50% Bb (black) and 50% bb (white), matching the ratio. So C also works. Options G and H are Bb × BB and BB × Bb respectively. These would produce the same results as F and A, right? Because regardless of which order you switch, it'll still be 50% Bb and 50% bb. So G and H are similar to F and A. Similarly, I is BB × bb, which would yield 25% BB (black) and 75% Bb (black), so the ratio is 1:3, which doesn't fit our problem. Wait, no, the problem says ¾ black, so I is incorrect. Option J is BB × BB. Both parents are homozygous dominant.

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: A scientist carries out a cross between two guinea pigs, both of which have black coats. Black hair coat is dominant over white hair coat. Three quarters of the offspring have black coats, and one quarter have white coats. The genotypes of the parents were most likely

A. Bb × Bb

B. BB × BB and Bb × bb

C. bb × Bb

D. bb × bb

E. bb × BB

F. Bb × bb

G. Bb × BB

H. BB × Bb

I. BB × bb

J. BB × BB

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Okay, so I'm trying to solve this genetics problem about guinea pigs. Let me read through it again carefully. The scenario is that a scientist crossed two guinea pigs, both with black coats. Black hair is dominant over white, so we know that the dominant trait (black) is expressed, and the recessive trait (white) isn't visible in the presence of the dominant version. The offspring's traits are ¾ black and ¼ white. The question is asking about the genotypes of the parents, specifically which combination would result in these offspring ratios. Let me break down what I remember from Mendelian genetics. Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. Given that all three-quarters of the offspring have black coats and one-quarter has white, that suggests a 3:1 ratio. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white). So, if we're looking at dihybrid crosses or other combinations, how do the parents' genotypes look? The options given are A to J, but let me list them: A. Bb × Bb  
B. BB × BB and Bb × bb  
C. bb × Bb  
D. bb × bb  
E. bb × BB  
F. Bb × bb  
G. Bb × BB  
H. BB × Bb  
I. BB × bb  
J. BB × BB Wait, actually, looking back, the user provided the possible answers as G, H, I, J, etc., but perhaps some of my notes might be off. Let me think more clearly. The key here is figuring out the genotype of the parents that would produce such a ratio when crossed. Since the ratio is ¾ black to ¼ white, this implies that in each offspring, there must be at least one dominant allele (B) present because the recessive condition (bb) leads to white. If a parent were homozygous recessive (bb), then every offspring would inherit a b from both parents, resulting in bb and hence white coats. So any parent who is bb would cause all their offspring to have white coats. However, since the parents aren't all producing white, they can't both be bb. Therefore, at least one parent must be heterozygous (Bb), giving some chance of passing on the dominant allele. But wait, let me consider the possible parent combinations: Option D is bb × bb. If both parents are bb, all their offspring would get bb from each, leading to all white coats. That doesn't match the given data, so D is out. Similarly, E is bb × BB. The bb parent will always give b, while the BB parent gives B. So all offspring would be Bb, resulting in black coats. Again, no white coats, so E is not correct. Now, F is Bb × bb. The bb parent always gives b, while Bb can give either B or b. So half the offspring will be Bb (black) and half bb (white). That matches the given ratio exactly. So F is a possibility. Looking further, let's check other options. Option A is Bb × Bb. Both parents are heterozygous. Using a Punnett square, the possible offspring would be BB (25%), Bb (50%), and bb (25%). But according to the problem, ¾ are black, which includes BB and Bb, and ¼ are white (only bb). That fits perfectly. So option A also works. Option C is bb × Bb. Similar to F, the bb parent gives b, and Bb can give B or b. So again, 50% Bb (black) and 50% bb (white), matching the ratio. So C also works. Options G and H are Bb × BB and BB × Bb respectively. These would produce the same results as F and A, right? Because regardless of which order you switch, it'll still be 50% Bb and 50% bb. So G and H are similar to F and A. Similarly, I is BB × bb, which would yield 25% BB (black) and 75% Bb (black), so the ratio is 1:3, which doesn't fit our problem. Wait, no, the problem says ¾ black, so I is incorrect. Option J is BB × BB. Both parents are homozygous dominant. All offspring would be BB, which means all black. That contradicts the ¾ black and ¼ white ratio. So J is wrong.

Now, considering the options:

- A: Bb × Bb → 1:3 (BB:25%, Bb:50%, bb:25%) → Doesn't fit, since ¾ should be black.
- B: BB × BB and Bb × bb → This seems like multiple parents involved, but the question states "the genotypes of the parents were most likely" implying a single pair of parents. So perhaps this is incorrect because it involves different parent types.
- C: bb × Bb → 50% Bb (black), 50% bb (white) → Fits the ratio.
- D: bb × bb → All white → Incorrect.
- E: bb × BB → All black → Incorrect.
- F: Bb × bb → Correct.
- G: Bb × BB → Same as F → Correct.
- H: BB × Bb → Same as C → Correct.
- I: BB × bb → Incorrect.
- J: BB × BB → Incorrect.

So the possible correct options are C, F, G, H. But looking back, the user asks for the most likely answer, implying a single choice. Let me re-examine. The correct ratio is ¾ black to ¼ white, which requires at least one dominant allele (B) in the offspring. If both parents are Bb, then the cross would result in 25% BB (black), 50% Bb (black), and 25% bb (white), totaling 75% black and 25% white. So A is correct. Alternatively, if one parent is Bb and the other is bb, the cross would be 50% Bb (black) and 50% bb (white), which also matches. So both A and C are possibilities, but looking at the options, the choices include A, C, F, G, H. However, since the question is asking for the most likely parents, I need to determine which is more probable based on the observed ratio. 

Wait, the problem provides four options for the parents: A is Bb × Bb; C is bb × Bb. Which one is more likely? If the parents are Bb × Bb, then the expected ratio is 3:1 (75% black, 25% white), which matches the problem statement. On the other hand, if the parents are bb × Bb, the ratio is also 1:1 (50% black, 50% white), which does not match the given ¾ black. Therefore, the parents must be Bb × Bb. Hence, the correct answer is A.

Black hair is dominant over white, so we know that the dominant trait (black) is expressed, and the recessive trait (white) isn't visible in the presence of the dominant version. The offspring's traits are ¾ black and ¼ white. The question is asking about the genotypes of the parents, specifically which combination would result in these offspring ratios. Let me break down what I remember from Mendelian genetics. Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. Given that all three-quarters of the offspring have black coats and one-quarter has white, that suggests a 3:1 ratio. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white). So, if we're looking at dihybrid crosses or other combinations, how do the parents' genotypes look? The options given are A to J, but let me list them: A. Bb × Bb  
B. BB × BB and Bb × bb  
C. bb × Bb  
D. bb × bb  
E. bb × BB  
F. Bb × bb  
G. Bb × BB  
H. BB × Bb  
I. BB × bb  
J. BB × BB Wait, actually, looking back, the user provided the possible answers as G, H, I, J, etc., but perhaps some of my notes might be off. Let me think more clearly. The key here is figuring out the genotype of the parents that would produce such a ratio when crossed. Since the ratio is ¾ black to ¼ white, this implies that in each offspring, there must be at least one dominant allele (B) present because the recessive condition (bb) leads to white. If a parent were homozygous recessive (bb), then every offspring would inherit a b from both parents, resulting in bb and hence white coats. So any parent who is bb would cause all their offspring to have white coats. However, since the parents aren't all producing white, they can't both be bb. Therefore, at least one parent must be heterozygous (Bb), giving some chance of passing on the dominant allele. But wait, let me consider the possible parent combinations: Option D is bb × bb. If both parents are bb, all their offspring would get bb from each, leading to all white coats. That doesn't match the given data, so D is out. Similarly, E is bb × BB. The bb parent will always give b, while the BB parent gives B. So all offspring would be Bb, resulting in black coats. Again, no white coats, so E is not correct. Now, F is Bb × bb. The bb parent always gives b, while Bb can give either B or b. So half the offspring will be Bb (black) and half bb (white). That matches the given ratio exactly. So F is a possibility. Looking further, let's check other options. Option A is Bb × Bb. Both parents are heterozygous. Using a Punnett square, the possible offspring would be BB (25%), Bb (50%), and bb (25%). But according to the problem, ¾ are black, which includes BB and Bb, and ¼ are white (only bb). That fits perfectly. So option A also works. Option C is bb × Bb. Similar to F, the bb parent gives b, and Bb can give B or b. So again, 50% Bb (black) and 50% bb (white), matching the ratio. So C also works. Options G and H are Bb × BB and BB × Bb respectively. These would produce the same results as F and A, right? Because regardless of which order you switch, it'll still be 50% Bb and 50% bb. So G and H are similar to F and A. Similarly, I is BB × bb, which would yield 25% BB (black) and 75% Bb (black), so the ratio is 1:3, which doesn't fit our problem. Wait, no, the problem says ¾ black, so I is incorrect. Option J is BB × BB. Both parents are homozygous dominant.
